awd_titl_txt: Harmonic Analysis and Machine Learning for Emergency Response
awd_abstract_narration:
The research presented in this project resides in threat detection and disaster management. Significant mathematical contributions to this field are still needed, due in part to the ongoing revolution with complex data problems, known as the Big Data paradigm. This project aims to bridge the big data gap, providing added value to the field while simultaneously expanding the impact of modern mathematics. With this point of view, this project studies potentially predictive disaster scenarios, from radioactive leaks, to modern battlefield issues, to natural disasters. However, the notion of threat in this project is not limited to an earthquake, flood, or nuclear explosion, but rather what impedes the people affected by disasters.  The project research intends to provide efficient ways of disaster aftermath management.

Algorithmic Threat Detection (ATD) is a predictive concept that must be quantified and effectively designed to address major defense problems.  After analysis of recent disaster scenarios, a suite of technologies have been formulated that use mathematics to help mitigate disaster impacts. Machine learning and deep learning are major techniques in this suite, and involve data processing, spectral graph analysis, Schroedinger eigenmap technology with customized non-linear potentials, transport models, and recent innovations, ideas, and results dealing with Fourier scattering transforms, pooling operators, and convolutional neural networks. Essentially, this work develops a toolkit from modern applied harmonic analysis and machine learning. The mathematical rigor in this work will enable us to construct fast and efficient disaster mitigation implementations.  The ideas and results proposed here are new and innovative, and the applications to threat detection are timely and relevant. These methods may also impact other areas of science.

por.por_cntn:
The project titled "ATD: Harmonic Analysis and Machine Learning for Emergency Response" (ID # 1738003) had four major objectives:
(1) To promote Harmonic Analysis-inspired and application oriented approaches in Machine Learning for solving difficult problems related to emergency response;
(2) To establish novel methodologies for feature extraction and aggregation, which will impact the fields of Deep Learning and Big Data processing;
(3) To provide numerically effective and efficient tools, based on concepts ranging from optimization to neural computations, for solving fundamental problems in Data Science and Machine Learning;
(4) To develop scientific interaction mechanisms, which enable the PIs to identify and solve problems of interest to a wide range of researchers, while providing new and novel training and professional development opportunities.


In regards to promoting Harmonic Analysis-inspired techniques for Machine Learning and Data Science, we used a broad approach, which ranged from introducing Fourier Scattering Transforms for feature extraction and data fusion, to proposing a novel MaxFun pooling function for output aggregation in neural networks. Time-frequency methods decompose spectra into multi-spectral bands, while hierarchical methods like neural networks incorporate information across scales and model multiple levels of dependencies between spectral features. The Fourier Scattering Transform arises thus as an amalgamation of time-frequency representations with neural network architectures. On the other hand, inspired by the Hardy--Littlewood maximal function originating from classical Harmonic Analysis, MaxFun pooling has demonstrated the ability to extract useful features from the input data sets for classification or segmentation purposes.


A primary contribution of our research is the demonstration of the representation capabilities of the aforementioned techniques, with a special emphasis on feature extraction and data aggregation, both of which play a fundamental role in emergency response applications. We showed that Fourier Scattering is well suited for the representation of a wide range of spectral modalities, including multispectral, hyperspectral, and ultraspectral imaging, in addition to panchromatic imagery, gamma radiation counts, or geolocation data. This is due to its ability to decompose signals into multi-frequency bands, while at the same time removing small perturbations such as e.g., geolocation noise. Furthermore, our results demonstrate that Fourier Scattering is highly effective in representing spectral data and superior to other spectral-spatial methods or state-of-the-art neural networks. We also studied the behavior of an object when primary sources of information about the object become unavailable, so that any information must be obtained from the intelligent use of available secondary sources. This process is called Reactive Sensing. Its theory is based on two equivalent ideas. The physical idea models signal strength and the sensitivity of sensors to such signal. The mathematical idea of multiplicative frames provides the factorization theory to compare quantitatively strength and sensitivity. This equivalence is the foundation for Reactive Sensing theory and its implementation. Together, Scattering Transforms and Reactive Sensing provide  complementary abilities to extract primary features from heterogeneous, large, noisy and complex data, as well as to replace the missing primary features with their secondary echos collected across the data spectrum.

To improve numerical efficiency, we explored representation capabilities of convolutional neural networks, leading to a novel technique that blends the Fourier Scattering Transform with a convolutional neural network. This method is naturally suited for representation of spectral data, while retaining the capability of the neural network to learn a hierarchical representation. We tested our proposed method on publicly available hyperspectral datasets, proving that our Blended Learning algorithm is effective at representing spectral data and less prone to overfitting the spatial bias. In order to resolve numerical issues inherent in complex and large datasets, we further augmented our representation toolbox with a new physics-inspired method based on the concept of transport models for graphs. The proposed approach generalizes existing dimension reduction and feature extraction algorithms, by replacing the role played by diffusion processes in estimating proximity, with dynamical systems based on advection and gradient flows. This approach allows us to exploit different and new relationships within the complex data structures. We demonstrate this by proposing a multi-scale algorithm in which transport models translate the information about contextual similarities of material classes to enhance feature extraction and classification results.

Together with our collaborators from Virginia Tech and DOE, we performed the Multi-Robot Radiation Search Experiment, which demonstrated the validity of our proposed approach for the problem of autonomous joint threat search. An end-to-end system capable of performing an initial survey with an aerial vehicle, then detecting interest points using our algorithms, and redeploying an unmanned vehicle to investigate these points, successfully tested our concepts in the field radiation search and mapping. This interdisciplinary effort led to novel training and development opportunities for our students. As a result, 16 PhDs were awarded to students of both PIs over the period of performance of this award (15 in Mathematics or Applied Mathematics, and 1 in Electrical Engineering).
